awd_titl_txt: MCB-ECA:  Assimilation of tree-ring and forest inventory data across the interior western U.S.: a hierarchical analysis of patterns and drivers to forecast forest productivity.
awd_abstract_narration:
Forests are influenced by climate. They also influence climate because they remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere as they grow. This project will better quantify both the influence of climate variation on tree growth and how much carbon is sequestered each year by forests by using two complementary data sets, the national forest inventory and tree-ring data. These data come from the U. S. Forest Service Forest Inventory and Analysis Program. This inventory program evaluates the current state and future trajectory of the nation's forests from measurements in a network of permanent sample plots. The plots are revisited and measurements are made once each decade in the western US. A spatially complete set of tree cores collected in the forest inventory plots contains information on the relationship between year-to-year variation in climate and tree growth, recorded in annual growth rings. The combined data will be used to study forest productivity across broad spatial scales and make predictions of ecosystem state, ecosystem services, and natural capital. This study will produce ecological forecasts relevant to society and informing strategies for climate adaptation. The project will also provide research experience and professional development for a post-doctoral fellow and undergraduates, open-source code for reproducible science, and outreach to schools and the public at the Laboratory of Tree-Ring Research at the University of Arizona. 

There is considerable uncertainty surrounding the future functioning of forest ecosystems, especially carbon sequestration, in the face of rising temperatures and evaporative demand. The focus of this project is the particularly vulnerable forest macrosystem of the interior western United States. Forest ecosystem functioning at this large scale will be analyzed by leveraging an existing, continental-scale ecological observatory network (the permanent sample plot network of the U. S. Forest Service's Forest Inventory and Analysis Program) and assimilating into it a new data stream with annual-resolution information on individual tree growth from increment cores collected in the same forest plot network. A hierarchical Bayesian multiple regression approach will be used to quantify the drivers of forest productivity across spatial scales and explain the effects of individual tree size, forest stand structure, geophysical conditions, disturbances, climate and their cross-scale interactions on tree-level and forest stand-level above-ground woody biomass production. Estimates of the effects of these drivers and their interactions will be used to make ecological forecasts of future tree- and stand-level productivity under various scenarios of stand density and stand size structure, including estimates of forecasting uncertainty. Data assimilation on this large scale will be supported by the cyberinfrastructure of NSF's CyVerse.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Forests have been slowing climate change by removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, but forests are also affected by climate change, and there is scientific uncertainty about whether they will continue to be a net carbon sink, faced with rising temperatures, drought, and increased forest disturbances. This project advanced our ability to quantify both sides of the feedback between forests and climate – the impact of climate variation on tree growth, and how much carbon is sequestered by trees – by leveraging an existing, continental-scale ecological observatory network (the forest plot network of the U. S. Forest Service’s Forest Inventory and Analysis Program) and adding new tree-ring data collected in the same forest plot network. Tree rings – the annual growth rings formed by many trees – are arguably the best source of information on how climate variation affects tree growth. Based at the world’s founding laboratory of dendrochronology, the Laboratory of Tree-Ring Research at the University of Arizona, and in collaboration with the U. S. Forest Service, the project generated more than 1,000 new time series of tree-ring widths across a vulnerable forested region, the interior western U. S., where forest inventory plots are visited (and trees measured) about every 10 years. Using advanced statistical approaches and NSF-supported data science cyberinfrastructure, we combined tree-ring data with 10-year measurements of tree stem diameter to determine the effects of temperature and precipitation variability on tree growth. All three tree species studied (ponderosa pine, Douglas-fir, common piñon), which are dominant across vast areas of the western U. S., are negatively impacted by warmer-than-average and drier-than-average conditions. Ecological forecasts through the end of the 21st century indicate slower tree growth (thus less forest carbon sequestration) and accumulating dead wood across the interior western U. S. under all future climate scenarios, but especially under the higher greenhouse gas emissions scenarios. Climate change itself is negatively impacting the ability of forests to slow climate change, compromising their ability to serve as a nature-based climate solution or negative emissions technology. The tree-ring data also provided convincing evidence against certain commonly used practices in ecological forecasting (space-for-time substitution, species distribution modeling), highlighting the risk that climate change may outpace the ability of tree species to adapt in place or move to newly suitable locations.

Over its 5-year duration (2018-2023), the project produced eleven scientific publications (e.g., in Nature Communications, the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences [3x], Global Change Biology [2x], BioScience, and Plant and Soil), including one that received the Ecological Society of America’s Ecological Forecasting Outstanding Publication Award, and three contributing to science-informed policy (e.g., a 58-page white paper, a chapter in the North American Carbon Program’s Science Implementation Plan). Further, the project provided training opportunities for one high school student, 12 undergraduates, one graduate student, and one post-doctoral fellow, and produced a series of videos on climate and carbon cycle literacy displayed in the Laboratory of Tree-Ring Research, which is open to the public and visited by thousands each year.

In summary, the project generated new data and tools to address the societal need to forecast future carbon sequestration by forests. The project advanced the practice of ecological forecasting, using leading-edge statistical and open-source, reproducible data science approaches, and highlighted the value of integrating tree-ring data with forest inventory data, stimulating new initiatives in the forest carbon-rich Pacific Northwest and Northeast U. S.
